At that point, accounting rules will be imposed on them, and they may have to pay more than for regular accounting in order to meet criteria that they may not necessarily control.
I do not see any progress in imposing the accounting obligation outside of any common framework for the European Union.
This is not merely a competition issue; it is quite simply a matter of economic integration, Community law, and equal treatment for all businesses within the European Union.
In other words, clearly, simplifying accounting requirements for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives, in fact, point in this direction, whether it be the proposal we are discussing today or the international framework IF.
whether it is the revision of the Fourth and Seventh Accounting Directives, for which the European Commission should soon be making proposals to us.
These proposals were promised to us for two thousand ten, it seems they are being extended, but I do not believe that this deadline extension is sufficient reason for this.
to rush and do a half-hearted job, as these three proposals, while sharing the same objective, may not have the same structure. It seems to me, Commissioner, that it would be better to

is clearer for businesses, providing them with a single, comprehensive solution that will enable them to reconcile the goal of simplifying obligations, desired by all, with the practical realities of small businesses that need it.
The current issue is that the European Commission is delaying the proposal to revise these directives, which is hindering our discussions.

I therefore call on the European Commission to expedite the dialogue on the issue of exemption, which today divides both European institutions and economic circles, and to conduct an impact assessment.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues, as my colleague Elisabeth Morin Chartier and others have pointed out, on February 27th and 28th, the violent storm Xintia struck several regions of France, causing fifty-three fatalities and immense material damage.
The storm was of rare intensity, causing devastating floods along the French coast.
After Madeira, Europe is once again affected.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Cadet, has been severely affected.
Three French departments have been declared in a state of natural disaster: Brittany, Poitou-Charentes, and Pays de la Loire.
In the face of these disasters, the European Union must demonstrate its responsiveness and express its solidarity.
It is not just through words and a resolution, but above all through financial assistance that we can support the victims of these disasters.

I therefore call on the European Commission to release the EU Solidarity Fund swiftly to assist the affected regions in dealing with the damage. My colleague Christophe Bchut joins me in this initiative.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European civil intervention force.

Europeans must act together because disasters are increasing and affecting our European territories, particularly our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Madam President, I too would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Jrg Leichtfried, on his text and his cooperative spirit in this matter. I particularly support his proposals on the financing of air safety, as we are talking here about air safety and not air security.

For many years, our committee has been advocating for the acceptance of the principle that stricter safety measures should be borne by the Member States, and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, security is not just a concern for travelers but for all citizens, and it is the responsibility of states to take measures to combat terrorism.
It is therefore unjustified for air passengers alone to bear the burden of financing security measures in airports and on board aircraft.
This is all the more so given that in transport modes such as rail and maritime, states fund, depending on the case, either partially or fully, security measures.
I therefore believe that we must stand firm against the Council and defend amendment thirty-two of the report adopted by our Transport Committee to the very end.
I had another point to briefly address.

While I support the progress on non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to establish a single, identical European system of safety fees.
While enforcing adherence to common rules, it is necessary to allow Member States to retain their current system of fee collection.

In states such as Spain, Italy, or France, royalties are voted on by Parliament, and in such cases, it is the authority responsible for challenging laws that must serve as the independent supervisory authority.
and this is the purpose of Amendment Forty, which I hope many of you will support when we vote on it.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the report I am presenting to Parliament attempts to explain that, in the fight against climate change, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature reminds us this week that volcanoes, in particular, can have a significant impact on human activities and the climate.
But this requires, nonetheless, that men, and Europe in particular, take responsibility to combat what is known as climate change.
My report attempts to demonstrate that agriculture can simultaneously continue to reduce its carbon emissions, decrease its consumption of fossil energy, and, above all, on the other hand,
side has actively contributed to carbon sequestration as part of a global effort to reduce carbon emissions and increase the amount of carbon captured and stored.
This report attempts to demonstrate that in agriculture, we should move away from a compartmentalized approach whereby every time we encounter a problem, we create a new directive.
on soils, on water, on pesticides, who knows what else, and trying to tackle the agricultural issue with the ambition to address it comprehensively, systematically.
In this approach, we need to identify ways to ensure that agriculture, as I mentioned earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption but also actively contributes to carbon sequestration.

It is particularly the role related to photosynthesis, biomass, and above all, what is dear to my heart, also linked to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to sequester organic carbon.

I believe that this avenue I am exploring in this report, and which I hope will be pursued during the vote in plenary session in Brussels, will enable European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability and ensure a...

ecological transition to this agriculture that would put it ahead of a number of other continents or other forms of agriculture, ensuring that it can be economically efficient, ecologically sound, and I believe also, from that point onwards, socially beneficial.

This report addresses a specific issue: the fight against climate change and agriculture. However, it aims, I hope, to open up other perspectives to feed, in particular, the debate on the future of agricultural policy after 2013.
I am addressing the Commission, and I will address, as I have often done, the agricultural committees, and I will also address the various ministers when the opportunity arises.
I believe we need to take a turn.
It is essential that this 2013 CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) be ambitious.
It is essential that it be based on objectives that enable citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because agricultural Europe must ensure both food security and commit to sustainability.
In any case, this is what I propose in this report, and I hope that the Parliament, by a large majority, will follow me on this.

Mr. President, I would like to emphasize first and foremost that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and temporary manner was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must take precedence over any other consideration, and under these circumstances, the attitude of certain airlines demanding the immediate and full reopening of airspace based on one or two test flights is, at the very least, indecent.

It was Mr. Hennin who, earlier, spoke about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with the train, and I will take this opportunity to express how much I regret the paralysis of air transport.
has been exacerbated in certain countries like France by the disruption of rail transport, caused by strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
Returning to our subject, I would like to commend the Commission's decision to authorize the granting of public aid to airline companies affected by the ongoing disruptions.
This is a decision driven by common sense in a context already marred by crisis, but such aid must be exceptional in nature.

In this regard, I hope that among the criteria considered for their award will be the exemplary nature demonstrated by companies in the compensation provided to their clients who were victims of flight cancellations.
Indeed, it is unacceptable for certain companies to abuse the force majeure clause to evade their obligation to compensate passengers as stipulated in Regulation 261/2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and, if no alternative solution is offered to them, they should not also bear the financial cost.
Moreover, travel agencies are exempt from the obligation to reimburse travelers for unused flights.
This is not normal either.

Companies, such as travel agencies, have insurance policies that cover them in exceptional circumstances, like the situation we have been experiencing for the past few days, and it is therefore essential to ensure that travelers are properly compensated for the flights that have been canceled.
Sir, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, catastrophe, disasterthe press is not short of words to describe the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been mentioned, particularly regarding the immense financial impact of this crisis, which could be described as abyssal, whether in direct or indirect terms.

While I welcome the possibility of considering the provision of exceptional public aid to the aviation sector, which has already been widely approved since September 11, 2001, I remain perplexed by Europe's management of these events.

Given that seven hundred and fifty European tour guides have been affected, many of whom remain stranded across the globe, and considering the economic losses which are exponentially growing with each passing day, how can it be explained that it took an inordinate amount of time to address this issue?

Not one, two, three, or four, but five days for the European Transport Ministers to meet via teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the establishment of differentiated traffic zones.
Two people do not dispute the necessity of applying the precautionary principle as an absolute priority, but today, as traffic is gradually being reauthorized in certain areas,
With the weather remaining unchanged and the volcano still active, the question arises as to what additional safety guarantees for passengers we could not have provided earlier, more quickly.

Thirdly, an adaptive action plan has been developed. The evolution of the situation depends on the weather and the volcanic activity, which can change from hour to hour. Who will continue to conduct updated assessments of the safety of the corridors?
Must these test flights be carried out by civil aviation and airlines?

Finally, if this persists, worsens, or recurswhich is likelythe established management model should provide for greater coordination among member states and special operational procedures based on real data, as well as improved

coordination of other transport means in exceptional circumstances, but also take into consideration the necessary coordination of assistance for the repatriation of the tens of thousands of stranded passengers, who also have the right to information and support.
So far, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.

Madam President, in turn, I would like to express my gratitude, following other speakers, to our colleague Mendes de Vigo, who has done remarkable work under sometimes passionate and always exciting conditions.
Debates within the Committee on Constitutional Affairs were lengthy, befitting the significance of the matter and reflecting the intense interest understandably held by all involved.
European Parliamentarians are rightly and primarily concerned with the major issue of the composition of our Assembly and the procedures for appointing its members.
Once again, the rapporteur has successfully gathered sometimes differing opinions and contributions, and has synthesized, I would say, in an extremely balanced text the various views and opinions.
I wanted to express my gratitude.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both the one concerning the convening of the IGC and the one regarding transitional measures for the composition of our Assembly, are characterized by realism, pragmatism, and effectiveness.
This is what, overall, on other topics as well, fellow citizens expect from Europe.
Mr. President, Mr. Dalli, Mr. Commissioner, it is with great conviction that this draft report, as presented a moment ago by Mr. Peterle, reiterates the key principles and objectives...
Director of Communication of the European Commission and is also inspired by the European Parliament resolution of 10 April 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to endorse the objectives of the European partnership envisioned by the European Commission to more effectively combat cancer, whether it be the importance of prevention, early detection, the development of a new cancer prevention model, and above all, the reduction of inequalities among Member States.
I share the concerns and worries expressed within the European Commission's communication and the draft report.
I would like to acknowledge the work done by Mr Peterli, rapporteur, in drafting this report and the compromise proposals put forward to incorporate the various amendments.

As a shadow rapporteur for the Socialist and Democrat Group, I have sought, among other things, to emphasize the following issues: firstly, the increase in annual cancer-related deaths caused by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, but also the importance of improved access to

Information on medications for cancer patients, as well as the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular updating of substances of very high concern that include carcinogenic substances, and support for initiatives to prevent the importation of goods.

containing chemical substances that are carcinogenic and strengthening the control of chemical substances within the European Union. Finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability that can include people suffering from chronic diseases or cancers.
These are the questions we have raised, while supporting this draft report.
Madam President, the oil well leak in the Gulf of Mexico is an outright ecological and economic catastrophe.
It would appear that irregularities have been identified in the granting by the United States Department of the Interior of forest permits.
This would be an unforgivable negligence with incalculable consequences, which do not only concern the United States of America.

When we consider that hundreds of offshore drilling permits are granted by governments worldwide, if these permits are issued with the same lack of caution, it would pose a significant problem for the entire globe.

elected representatives from the European Union's outermost regions and the Overseas Countries and Territories, which are either entirely or almost entirely composed of islands, numbering close to one hundred and thirty.
In total, spread across the three continents, I must express here my profound concern for our islands regarding offshore oil exploration projects.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, as a role model, rigorously re-examines its security and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
In addition, accidental or operational offshore oil spills, not necessarily originating from Europe, are estimated at several tens of thousands of tonnes each year.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives to ensure that offshore platforms now fall under the purview of an uncontested international scientific authority, which should be established in the form of an international body?
After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would do well to initiate genuine global governance for the exploration, protection, and exploitation of deep-sea resources.
Building on the Barcelona Process, the Union for the Mediterranean presents an opportunity to develop our relations with the countries of the eastern and southern Mediterranean basin.
As highlighted in the excellent report by Vincent Payon, we cannot overlook either the potential of this region or the perils it entails.
However, let us have the lucidity to acknowledge that, following the bombing of Gaza and with the ongoing colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is at an impasse.
The political aspect is blocked.
We are not even certain that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will actually take place.
I would not be surprised if we learn, in the coming hours or days, that he is in critical condition.
We must not give up, but the European Union needs to take greater responsibility in the search for a political solution.
We cannot allow the United States to have a monopoly on the political management of the crisis in this region, which is ours, by merely contributing to its development.
The development and stability of the Mediterranean region underpin our security and growth, and for this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best tool at our disposal.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this is an extremely important matter regarding consumer protection.

A recent survey shows that the situation regarding food security has deteriorated over the past ten years in the eyes of Europeans, and one in three consumers remains skeptical about the quality of products.
Therefore, updating, simplifying, and clarifying food labeling in the European Union is an obligation for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color-coding, we are in favor of this system provided it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional values expressed as percentages.
I am opposed to mandatory nutritional labeling for wines and spirits.
We advocate for the development of a regulation specific to wines and spirits within the next three years, rather than the five years proposed by the European Commission.
This is what I wished to point out, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, this attack on civilian vessels by Israeli commandos clearly demands an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credibility could we attribute to a Commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack took place in international waters, and thus concerns the international community, particularly the European countries bordering the Mediterranean.
Europe should make its voice heard more loudly and engage more actively in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making significant financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately, it is largely absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of a Palestinian state.
The financial and budgetary goodwill we demonstrate is not enough.
We must also express political will and take the necessary steps to make our voices heard.
The abrupt replacement of the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army has sparked emotion and condemnation.
emotion before the nine victims of the civilian assault, condemnation because this boarding in international waters constitutes a violation of international law.

In doing so, the government of Israel is penalizing its own people, for ultimately, we see that with the strengthening of extremes, the goal of achieving security in the region is moving further out of reach.
Yes, now more than ever, the government of Israel must abandon the policy of force.
I would like to point out, however, that the extensive media coverage of the Mavi Marmara flotilla, orchestrated from Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation appears indispensable to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
And I hope that the government of Israel will agree to include substantial international participation in this investigation to finally find the paths to justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I welcome the new momentum generated by the launch of the partnership for modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if it were to achieve nothing else, would at least have the merit of underscoring the extent to which Russia is an indispensable geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also welcome the positive remarks on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the demands of the Union are always prioritized, the interests or positions of its partner are systematically undervalued or disregarded, whether in the field of energy or in how it may analyze the Eastern Partnership and the Atlantic aspirations of its closest neighbors.

I also note that the firmness demonstrated by most member states of the Union in their speeches, the virulence of their condemnations of human rights violations, seem to be reserved solely for Russia.

The rhetoric is more cautious, the diplomacy more nuanced, as if it were about China, for example, these systematic violations of the rule of law, not to mention the Laogai, this global factory in relation to minimal European social standards, when our French or European workers are unemployed.

Let me remind you of the adage "From the father's toil, the heights by narrow paths," for this is how I view the efforts of today's Russia, freed from the criminal Marxist poison that bled and shackled this country for so many decades.
The current Russian Confederation has managed to lift the spirits of an entire nation despite the significant difficulties and challenges that remain to be overcome.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen Europhiles, especially when the super European state, for its part, fails to achieve any of its fine objectives, despite increasingly costly means and the progressive domination of the states of Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but recall that this Assembly showed more leniency towards the communist Soviet Union than it did towards Russia.

It is often the same individuals who, yesterday, advocated for the unilateral disarmament of the West and participation in Mr. Gorbachev's common house, who today express the most virtuous indignation and the greatest modesty towards the Russia-Union partnership.

On this matter, I must inform you, in case you are not already aware, of new historical facts that are emerging due to the gradual translation of Soviet secret archives. A courageous individual, Mr. Pavel Stroilov, has managed to obtain these archives, which have already revealed and will continue to unveil much information.

unpleasant surprise to the classic of monolithic thinking regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was truly Mr. Gorbachev, and the deception of today's powerful Europhiles who then, with enthusiasm, wanted to make certain Soviet projects possible.
At the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for the European states, and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties.

This country is far closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interests, and shared risks than are certain states that you are nonetheless preparing to admit to the European Union.
President of the Council, it is often said that necessity makes law.
In the face of the crisis, an evident truth emerges, expressing an inevitable necessity: the need to innovate and be creative.

In this regard, I welcome the step taken by the Council, a step which I hope will ultimately be a giant leap towards genuine economic governance, because let us not be mistaken, mere coordination of economic policies will remain inadequate.
Can we achieve a true budgetary federation, not forced by circumstances, but because we ourselves have decided it?
Let us return to the Council's decisions, which nonetheless please me.
Strengthening the preventive aspect of the Stability and Growth Pact is a positive step, but there can be no true budgetary discipline without sanctions for those who fail to comply.
They have been strengthened but not yet specified, which is a regret.

Otherwise, I will express my satisfaction, among other things, with regard to the decided orientations, such as the famous competitiveness assessment dashboard, because that is indeed what it is about: regaining competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
Let us also welcome the proposal to introduce a bank tax, the acceptance of a financial transactions tax, and the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, all these decisions and orientations seemed, a few months ago, or even a few weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, or even truly hypothetical.
You are correct, it is true, it is a profound cultural shift on the scale of European incremental policy.
In saying this, it is now imperative that in October, the states very concretely implement these guidelines.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic giant leap or merely a pious hope, which we will all bitterly regret, and in particular, a majority of citizens will have to endure on a daily basis. Thank you.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on the Gallo report, and clearly, the Parliament and all groups still need to discuss it further since there are contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
That is why we were requesting that the debate and vote on the Gallo report be postponed until September 2nd, when we will need to consult with the Conference of Presidents.
So, it's a very simple thing.
Given that the fruit is not ripe, let's give it the summer to mature and discuss it in September.

Madam President, I must admit that I struggle to follow my colleagues who are so keen to flex their muscles and claim an exclusive hold on our legitimacy in comparison to the other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisory.
But when the members of this house, through hard work and conviction, assert a well-argued position, when
We are advocating for what resembles a European common interest against rigid states; the situation changes completely.
In this debate on European supervision, the Parliament has played that role.
Regarding the European Systemic Risk Board, for which I serve as my group's shadow rapporteur, I have advocated, like the rapporteur, Ms. Goulard, for an ambitious approach.
I have advocated for mechanisms that ensure a certain efficiency, and I have emphasized the preeminence of the European Central Bank.
Why?
because the European Central Bank is indeed the only Community institution in this group and because it has demonstrated its seriousness.
Out of Christian charity, I shall refrain from naming all the institutions and those great figures who suddenly vanished during the storm,
We can consider ourselves fortunate to have had at least one captain on board at the height of the crisis.
I will therefore be reassured to see tomorrow's macro-prudential supervision supported by a strong community institution, while micro-prudential supervision will inevitably remain fragmented.
In these troubled times, the European Systemic Risk Board must begin its work as soon as possible.
The future will reveal whether adjustments are necessary, but it is crucial to start from a sound foundation as systemic risks impact the entire European and global banking sector.
Mr. President, the final agreement reached on the overhaul of the directives relating to industrial emissions is more than acceptable, and I commend the compromise work that has been done.

This final package incorporates the key points of the position that I advocated for, along with several of my colleagues on the environment committee, aiming to make this text a bold yet realistic legislation.
Firstly, maintaining a degree of flexibility for businesses and competent authorities in granting exemptions.
Next, I would like to acknowledge the new version of the ESN, which has been so controversial and now, limited to certain sectors, seems much more feasible.

It is also important to emphasize that the agreement reached allows for better alignment with the ETS Directive and permanently removes the somewhat irrelevant idea of creating a SO2 and NOx quota market from the text of the new directive.
A few caveats to bear in mind, however, and more specifically the provisions relating to the ground.
The soil directive still pending, this important issue will unfortunately only be addressed by those Member States with their own specific legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament must adopt the elements of the agreement reached following the trilogues.

Enormous efforts have been made from all sides to avoid sending this text to conciliation, a text which, I must remind you, is of crucial importance, both for industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, each day brings new information revealing the full scale of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico by the offshore platform rupture.
But let us not forget that other disasters of this kind are happening elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today, and has been for a long time, in Nigeria.

That is why, in addition to the moratorium on new drilling, I believe there is a need to promote stricter rules regarding platform management, not just European rules but also international regulations.
As far as the European Union is concerned, I believe it is necessary for it to proactively equip itself with tools to combat this disaster, and I think it is evident.
as all this argues, as Mrs Damanaky said, for a firm and resolute choice in favour of clean and renewable energies,
And the European Union should lead by example in this regard.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur while the European Union is set to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence on the part of the Commission.
Europe already imports five hundred thousand tonnes of beef.
A new opening of our market will be to the detriment of breeders in European disadvantaged areas, without any guarantee of compliance with health and social standards.
We cannot accept this.
Europe purchases thirty-eight million tonnes of soybeans and animal feed.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize over nineteen million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies: Cargill, ADM, and Bunch.
Between 2001 and 2004, soy destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
This is one of the primary causes of the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the loss of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of autonomy in plant proteins for livestock feed.
Environmentally-friendly agriculture and the fight against climate change dictate this choice.
These efforts will be undermined by this draft bilateral agreement.
Once again, the European Commission is sacrificing its agriculture and farmers to obtain uncertain concessions for service sector businesses.
These concessions will not benefit the peasant families of Mercosur, but rather the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To convince oneself of this, one need only read the report by Tyson, the American company that is a heavyweight on the international meat market,
who announces having invested in Brazil, to quote him and as stated in his report, to use this country as an export platform for Europe.
Other companies, like Doux, had already anticipated this move by acquiring the Brazilian group Frango Soul in 1998.
Many poultry farmers, particularly in Brittany, bore the brunt of this operation.
Europe appears to be intent on continuing its policy of offshoring by intensifying its attacks.
against the peasants. We must stop
Mr. President, many colleagues are concerned about the potential impact on European agriculture that the reopening of negotiations for an association agreement with Mercosur could have.
My group and I share these concerns.

Indeed, it is to be feared, and as a representative of an ultra-peripheral region, I have experience with the banana agreements. Therefore, it is to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur could deal a severe blow to many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.
There is also a concern that this agreement may further shift the agriculture of Mercosur countries towards a productivist model, to the detriment of small-scale farms that exist in these nations.
A balance must therefore be struck so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers rooted essentially in the dogma of mercantilism.
Mr. President, I would like to simply say that perhaps we did not manage our agenda well today after all.
If we allow free trade agreements to bring into Europe's territory products that do not comply with our social standards or our environmental standards, the reform of the CAP will be useless.
In very clear terms, we cannot remain in a state of hypocrisy where, on the one hand, we impose environmental, health traceability, and safety constraints,
to our farmers, on the grounds that consumers must be protected, and on the other hand, allowing products that can enter our continent freely without adhering to these standards.
The question that is being raised behind the negotiation with Mercosur is indeed this one.

And the way things have been initiated, regardless of what we are told about the Parliament being well-informed and the process being conducted with the utmost transparency and clarity, does not lead us to form a positive assessment of a negotiation that is taking place while, in parallel, negotiations at the WTO continue.
In the name of consistency, consumer protection, and the defense of our farmers, I do not believe we should continue down this path.

Madam President, I would also like to acknowledge the work done by the rapporteur, Jos Bov, to welcome the Commissioner, and to acknowledge Mr Dess's contribution before me on the objectives of this report.
I believe it is crucial to keep in mind that in our debate, we are addressing an issue related to price volatility in agriculture, and particularly to the fact that when prices
When prices rise at the production level, these increases are very quickly reflected in distribution, but when prices fall at the production level, there are no corresponding decreases for consumers.
There is indeed an issue with the organization of the sector, and there is also a problem with the distribution of what is known as value added within the sector.

I believe that Jos Bov's report provides, on several points, perspectives that should be highlighted, and here I am really addressing the Commission to try to break out of this fundamentally negative spiral.
The first, of course, is the organization of the supply chain and the power dynamics within it. And so,
What proposals do we have to ensure that organized, collective producers have more influence within the sector to negotiate?
This is the question you raised, Mr. Interprofessional Commissioner, but it is also a question that arises from the contractual basis that will be established.
I argue that it is essential for this contractual basis to have a European framework, as outlined in the report.
We cannot leave it to each country to solve this problem.
There must be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
This is a proposal, an inseparable lead for me.
Secondly, of course, the issue of price transparency.
And here, I am in favor of establishing this observatory, which is absolutely necessary to enable us to inform consumers about price developments.
I support the proposals that have been put forward and, as Mr Dess said, I hope there will be a majority to follow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, today I would like to welcome this debate, which once again highlights the need for the Union to recognize and valorize its regional diversity.
In these times of negotiation for the new 2014 framework programs, it seems important to me to highlight the adjustments that specific regions must benefit from.
Issues of territorial continuity and cohesion must be at the forefront of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous, insular, or sparsely populated territories requires more than a set of derogatory measures.
We need a horizontal approach.
We need to establish the instruments that can synergistically coexist all areas of community action in order to enhance their added value.

Furthermore, as a representative of the outermost regions, I eagerly await the new Union strategy for the OUTR, which the Commission services have promised us for the beginning of two thousand and eleven.
Madam President, Commissioner, and dear colleagues, firstly, I align myself with my colleague's position on the Council's absence from this Parliament meeting.
I find this a bit cavalier on the Council's part, I also want to say.
As the upcoming summit of October 6th approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely strive to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at this very time, we were already busy in this very hemicycle urging Europe to do everything in its power to reach an ambitious and binding agreement in Copenhagen.
We have seen that the result did not meet our expectations and ambitions.
So the concerns a year later are the same, if not even more acute.

In order to constrain or convince our partners today, we must demonstrate that our resolve is absolutely intact, showing, for instance, that we are equipping ourselves with the means to honor our commitments to the countries of the Global South.
For this, the implementation of innovative financing mechanisms, and I heard yesterday President Sarkozy's speech at the UN, is becoming a necessary evidence.
So, for instance, the introduction of a carbon tax at our borders is not to be excluded.

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not going far enough in their climate commitments, and much more than a threat ultimately, and a way to protect our jobs and businesses, especially to better address the post-crisis period.

Madam President, in my view, the need to revalue family leave is not approved. Increasing the minimum threshold for maternity leave is a step forward, a benefit, and we should not be entirely demagogic in comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are difficult to quantify.

But the problem is essentially twofold: one, the economic context, which is true, but not sufficient to leave millions of families stranded for decades more; two, the legal gaps in the report, as the text contains several types of family leave whose legal bases are not reconcilable.
Let's consider the adoption leave included in the text on the same footing as maternity and paternity leave.
Personally, as an adoptive mother and for all those I represent, I appreciate the willingness to grant rights equivalent to those of biological mothers.
In fact, I am the small additional package that Mrs. Morin mentioned to be added to the Estrella report.

If the goal is indeed to enhance the health and rights of all women in the labor market, adopting mothers, having become mothers just like the others, are entitled to the same rights and the same workplace protection.
They are mothers like any others, fully entitled to adopt a child whether it is over or under twelve months old. Moreover, there is no discrimination, as the text specifies.
As for adoption, I regret that the text was not more thoroughly explored.
It was not even informed by the Rambol impact study.
All of this is not well developed, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these reservations, I will support Mrs Estrella's report because, beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better fulfill their parental responsibilities in a society that

increasingly abdicating its responsibility in the education of these young people, but moreover, because it is our duty to ensure that no one has to choose between sacrificing their children for their work or sacrificing their work for their children.
Finally, we do not sit on the Council, but in Parliament. If we, the directly elected representatives, are not ambitious, tell me who will be.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would like to intervene and not revisit the debate as it has unfolded thus far.
We discussed a 2011 budget within the constraints we know, namely the deep crisis facing Europe, with national public deficits that could lead to two hypotheses.
These national public deficits constrain the European deficit, or these deficits at the national level must provide a new direction and a fresh impetus at the European scale.
That is the question.
I ask you, Commissioner, above all to try to think, when we discuss a budget revision, when we are about to start talking about budgetary perspectives beyond 2013, not to
Remaining completely immersed in the context of the crisis, unless I am to say and to tell all European citizens that, resolutely, Europe will remain in crisis for a long time.
Our entire problem is indeed managing the crisis and reducing our deficits and debt, but it is also about preparing for the post-crisis period.
And this is where the budget question arises.

We will only be able to emerge from the crisis, as Joseph Dole immediately pointed out, if the European budget, precisely because it is European, can provide us with the means to regain what is currently lacking in terms of growth, job creation, innovation, and research.

This is the crux of the matter, and it is in this context that we must discuss the budget, rather than constantly incorporating, as we too often do, the issue of the crisis and the question of deficits, in which the Council excels.

I have observed that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even preemptively announced a treaty reform without even discussing with Mr. van Rompuy anything at all to penalize all states that would not respect budgetary discipline tomorrow.

This is where we stand at the Council level today, as Parliament is only asking for one thing, especially from the Commission, which is to try to drive the European project forward, and this is done through the budget.
You have noted a number of points on which we are in complete agreement.
There is a need for greater flexibility.
Obviously, we need to collectively find a way to have a much more flexible budget, as it is a matter of necessity and the reactivity of Europe is at stake.
It is also, of course, a matter of setting priorities and organizing the effectiveness of the European budget.
We will all agree on this, all in agreement, it is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear with each other is that we must have a timetable; we need to set joint objectives together, Commissioner. It cannot remain just words, just commitments, just

texts which are, incidentally, very interesting and which I agree with almost one hundred percent. But now, we need to get down to the specifics, particularly on a crucial issue that we keep circling around: own-resources.

How can we ensure clean resources for Europe's citizens tomorrow, not just for Europe, but for all European citizens, and how can we collectively find our way back to growth and an even stronger path for Europe's future?
It is your turn, Commissioner.
Mr. President, I would like to focus my remarks on the preparation of the upcoming G20 summits.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers regarding European economic governance, the need to strengthen European economic governance, to reinforce the Stability and Growth Pact, and to better involve the European Parliament and, of course, national parliaments in the process.
I would like to briefly mention two challenges facing our nations, and facing the members of the G20, which, in my view, must be addressed in the context of the upcoming G20 meetings.
the challenge of the currency war and that of the volatility of raw material prices.
I believe that on these two issues, which are genuine threats to global growth and cause significant imbalances on our planet, the European Union must take action.

European manages to organize itself, to adopt common positions, to give itself the means to speak with one voice at the upcoming G20 summits, in Seoul and also those to follow, and more broadly on the world stage. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Fejo on the quality of the report and the ambitious proposals it contains.
This also demonstrates that the European Parliament is fully engaged in a debate that is crucial for Europe's future, and we can only commend this.
Moreover, the Greek crisis served as a revealer of the dysfunctions undermining the economic governance of the European Union.
I note on this point Mr. Feyot's proposal to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability.
We must also address the problem at its root.
For this, I believe the solution also lies in strengthening the Stability and Growth Pact, particularly the sanctions.
This is essential if we want to achieve a sustainable improvement in the budgetary situation of states, which is not always popular.
It is restrictive, but we have no choice.

I believe that the report clearly highlights the issues surrounding the marine environment in terms of fisheries, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological resources, and research, combined with climate change.
This is a considerable development potential that should be secured, protected, and sustainably enhanced, as the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also rightly notes that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its outermost regions provide it with the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
In light of such a finding, it is therefore the responsibility of the European Union to implement an ambitious policy, a major maritime policy.
If it is not the world's leading naval power that does it, who will do it in its place?
But it must be acknowledged that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with fifty million euros that one can aspire to hold a leadership position in world politics.
Finally, while the ultra-peripheral regions have a recognized strategic position as they are present in all oceans, it would seem that
It was wise to give them a leading role in a grand ocean strategy, which, unfortunately, was not retained in the report, and I regret that. Thank you, Mr. President.
Madam Commissioner, Sir, I would like to revisit the anti-counterfeiting agreement currently being negotiated, particularly with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, particularly among officials at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Moreover, seventy-five American law professors have just sent a letter to President Obama.
He deems that ACTA, a mere executive agreement, would be contrary to the American Constitution.
As the European Parliament is set, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, it continues to raise significant concerns and is far from achieving unanimous support.
Among our fellow citizens, I think it would be useful to have a very clear response from our American interlocutors on two points: Can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA, in their eyes, a binding or voluntary agreement?
Indeed, an anti-counterfeiting agreement already absent of China, India, and Brazil, which is not implemented by the United States, would significantly lose its credibility.
I thank you.

Mr. President, throughout this difficult birth of the directive on alternative funds, I have consistently advocated for the principle of equal treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle may sound like an obvious truth, but that truth has encountered countless difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory in nature.
I would like to thank the negotiators, and in particular our rapporteur, Mr. Gauzs, who, after this particularly painful delivery for him, deserves a substantial maternity leave.
I would like to emphasize above all that the issue of the treatment of third countries must still be considered from two perspectives, whether one is inside or outside the European Union.
Thanks in large part to the European Parliament, all funds sold in the European Union will effectively be subject to comparable regulation.
One can then speak of more or less fair playing conditions.

It remains that, during the transitional period, non-European entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while funds and managers from the European Union will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter.
The situation is different in markets located outside the European Union. There, European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for third-country funds.
It would then be much more difficult to sell European products in the rest of the world as they will be less flexible and more expensive.
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was to some extent inevitable.

As for depositaries, let us also be aware that we will make the task more demanding, particularly due to the new responsibilities that will fall upon them. The increase in costs should lead to substantial changes in the profession.

Mr. President, I am not saying this to express my opposition, but to point out that this new regulation is not trivial. Its implementation, which is necessary, will also present challenges that we must be aware of.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, especially at the beginning of the 21st century, patients require appropriate information to be fully engaged in their care journey, to know where to seek treatment, to decide on the best course of treatment in consultation with healthcare professionals, and to strictly adhere to the prescribed treatment plan.
Today, patients demand independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.
Unfortunately, the proposals for revising the directive submitted by the European Commission did not adequately address the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which we consider to be a nonsensical approach in terms of addressing the actual needs of patients.
This operation holds no interest for either citizens or member states.
It means, in contrast to additional bureaucracy, an increase in spending and putting patients at risk.
It is for these reasons that we initially submitted a proposal to reject these texts, thereby requesting the Commission to revise its approach.

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Carl Schlitter from the Greens group, enabled our rapporteur, Mr Fechner, whom I welcome, to undertake a significant revision of the Commission's proposals.

In parallel, we had tabled around sixty amendments aimed at further protecting the health of our citizens and facilitating patients' access to independent, comparative information tailored to individual needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the environmental committee has enabled a greater emphasis on patients' right to information, rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.

In light of the compromise amendments secured, we have resolved to withdraw our proposal to reject the texts, as the substance of the text has evolved in a positive direction over the past few months.
The draft report, as amended, has succeeded in counterbalancing the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to oppose the instrumentalization of healthcare professionals to distribute brochures and information provided by pharmaceutical companies to their patients without any oversight from health authorities.
Similarly, we will oppose the authorization of industrial-scale information campaigns, particularly regarding vaccination.
Information cannot freely flow from pharmaceutical firms.

Experience shows that we need to be very vigilant. Indeed, and to conclude, the events surrounding the drug Mediator demonstrate the extent to which we must remain vigilant and ensure that this balance point, which we sought to achieve with this draft report, is maintained.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister, unity and realism will, I hope, be reflected in tomorrow's vote on our resolution for this sixteenth conference of the parties on climate change.

I hope that our commissioner in charge will be able to advance the pragmatic objectives that we must collectively achieve, while also upholding the non-negotiable conditions set by Europe that are associated with them.
In these negotiations, we must also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of fairness from our fellow citizens and industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change, not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of intellectual property that is far too little protected will be essential.
Green technologies should benefit the greatest number, but we must not, for all that, sell off our present and future knowledge, even for this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, requesting common methods for calculating emissions, as well as the verification and publication of data, so that all emitting industries are subject to the same standard, seems to be a most legitimate request and not a negotiating tactic.
Finally, and this is more contentious, as my colleague mentioned earlier, the shortcomings of the current clean development mechanism system will also need to be addressed.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, to our regret, that the true negotiating power is not held by the European Parliament.

But the willingness of many European parliamentarians, including myself, to work and contribute to a positive outcome of this conference should be encouraged, not neglected, as we have felt in recent days.
If Europe aims to be strong within international dialogues, the same must be true for all its legislators.
Madam President, the European Union often presents economic partnership agreements as an opportunity for African countries.
Is she despairing, then, that these agreements are not signed as soon as possible?
But the question that intrigues us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so beneficial to them.
Clearly, assessments differ regarding the quality of these agreements, and as long as these discrepancies persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Would it not be appropriate to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
These actors wish to discuss development strategy, while Europe often responds solely with market opening.
It is this listening that the ACP-European Union Joint Parliamentary Assembly imposes upon itself.
I believe that other European institutions should follow suit if we are to build a genuine strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Christians are undoubtedly one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, "legitimate targets," with the goal being their complete and utter departure from this region, a region that saw the birth of Christianity and where their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events at the Baghdad cathedral are merely the culmination of a situation we have passively observed for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and trading partner of many countries in this region, must strongly express its indignation in light of the situation.
Any and all forms of discrimination are intolerable.
Democracy will only triumph in this region when the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
Dear colleagues, we are all confronted with the serious crisis currently prevailing in Cte d'Ivoire.

It is evident that the decision of this country's Constitutional Council to challenge, in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the independent electoral commission, is unanimously condemned by the international community.

The European Union, the UN, the African Union, the Joint Parliamentary Assembly European Union-ACP, the COAS, and soon, undoubtedly, the European Parliament, are calling for the respect of the official proclamation of the
the election results and the inauguration of the new President of the Republic as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission, which, I remind you, is a body validated by the United Nations.
All political groups in the European Parliament have expressed, in a joint statement, their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for a halt to any escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be a human, social, and economic disaster for Cte d'Ivoire, something that must obviously be avoided at all costs.

Madam President, I in turn would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done remarkable work and have significantly enhanced the value of the European Parliament's contribution to the text initially proposed by the Commission.
The citizen's initiative that we in the EPP are about to vote on enthusiastically is a major advancement of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let us not be mistaken, this instrument can truly transform the European political landscape, provided it is used with both responsibility and boldness. I emphasize, responsibility and boldness.
It can help bring European citizens directly into the European political debate.
It can help to foster a European public opinion, that is, men and women who are citizens of Europe, debating together, taking positions together, and rallying around truly European issues.
But let us not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let us urge our member states to swiftly adopt the implementing measures where necessary; let us not disappoint our fellow citizens. The strengthening of European democracy is at stake.
I, like several of our colleagues, wished to address the issue of the persecution of Christians around the world, particularly the Christians of the East.
There is no need to recall the horrible acts recently perpetrated.
I would like to solemnly recall that defending Christians in the East as well as everywhere around the world, advocating for religious freedom and the diversity of beliefs, is a fundamental duty.
Believing in these principles means advocating for freedom, democracy, and human rights, which are values at the core of the European project and, indeed, we are all convinced here, universal values.
It is high time now, beyond indignation, emotion, and solemn condemnations, to move from words to action.
I urgently call on the authorities of the European Union, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, as well as all our leaders, the Ministers of Foreign Affairs,
Implement precise measures, establish a clear and concrete plan of action to make respect for religious diversity and the fight against all forms of religious persecution a priority. Thank you.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, High Representative, we all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has significantly deteriorated.
and allowing a lawless zone to establish itself in Europe's ports is a danger we must firmly and promptly combat.
Extremist groups are proliferating and threatening the lives of civilian populations.
In my turn, I deplore the loss of life and hostage-takings, and I am concerned for the European citizens on the ground.
Until now, Morocco has been a bulwark against all kinds of trafficking from the Sahel.
Now, drug, arms, or human traffickers are bypassing Morocco by transiting through Mauritania to the Canary Islands en route to the European Union.
It is, it seems to me, the responsibility of the European Union to act to help its states put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake not only on our territory but also in its immediate neighborhood.
It is time for us to act, and I call on the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to assist in the return to security in the Sahel.
That has been said, but I associate myself with the expressions of sympathy and support that have already been extended to the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples.
He represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to state that the European Union, which, as has been mentioned, has been criticized for its lack of response, must firmly stand alongside the Tunisian and Egyptian people to help them successfully open their countries to reform and establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support Tunisian leaders in initiating a peaceful transition, preparing the organization of upcoming elections to achieve freedom and enable the Tunisian people to attain the prosperity of development and social peace, an economy that will allow youth to find employment.

I would say in conclusion that the Union for the Mediterranean faces a significant challenge because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave across all the states of the Maghreb, the Near East, and the Middle East.
She must implement a robust strategy towards these countries.

But beware, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for the legitimate aspirations of the people, and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have reminded us on numerous occasions.

At a time when Europe is questioning itself about a common strategy for its supply of raw materials, and particularly rare earths, we cannot neglect the immense potential represented by the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthening European standards to improve the operation of collection chains, addressing issues of leakage or illegal export of dies, and increasing our collection targets should be at the heart of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor in the success or failure of this regulation: the consumer.
Citizen empowerment is crucial if we are to implement effective legislation.
And to achieve this, my dear Karl Heinz, the eco-contribution, among other systems, has proven to be one of the most relevant tools.
Electric and electronic equipment producers must, of course, become more involved in the collection and recycling system, but we cannot absolve citizens of responsibility for the waste they generate.
Our citizens must be actors, not spectators, of European environmental policy.

Madam President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to begin by echoing the remark just made by Ms. McGuinness regarding the essential link between the food issue and the agricultural question.
The issue that concerns us is the rise in food prices, and the consequences this may have for numerous populations around the world, including in Europe.
I would first like to try to share an observation.

The tendency towards increasing agricultural prices and agricultural raw materials prices is, for me, a long-term trend that will persist for three essential reasons: the world's demographic evolution and the resulting increase in demand, the rise in production costs, and the limited elasticity of supply in the agricultural sector.

of the global population. Second, the fact that with climate change, we have entered a phase of climatic events that pose problems, whether it be drought or flooding. And the third point is because the world is also developing.
With new emerging countries, consumption levels are rising.
Thus, the tension in agricultural markets and agricultural commodity markets is a significant and persistent trend.
It is exacerbated by price volatility, and price volatility is a consequence of the financialization of the global economy.
And it is on this subject that we must also focus if we are to resolve the agricultural and food issues.

And to achieve this, what the commissioner said is important; there are two key elements: yes, there needs to be transparency regarding stocks, but there also needs to be a public stock policy in Europe and stock management on a global scale, particularly at the level of the UN.

Second point, there needs to be regulation of financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing to allow speculative volume to become completely disconnected from the physical quantities traded on the markets.
We cannot accept that, on the issue of food, speculators come to speculate without considering the consequences this may have, as it concerns the food of the world and humanity. I conclude by saying
This leads to two major consequences: we need a strong European policy, and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to being a global player in food and agriculture.

Secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, on a global scale and with Europe as an actor, we reinvest in agriculture because we will need all forms of agriculture to feed the world.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, as in 2008, the price of agricultural raw materials is soaring on global markets.
We are only three levels below the two thousand eight level.
The decline in production in certain traditional export zones, due to climate change, the diversion of cereals to agrofuel production, and speculation.
Financial actions have had upward effects, and are responsible for this situation, as shown in reports from the IMF, French authorities, and as also stated by the Commission.
The consequences of this new food crisis are severely affecting the 1.2 billion people worldwide who live on less than $1.50 a day.
Since the month of October, an additional forty-four million people have joined those living below the poverty line.
With two days until the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those approved in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the U.S. administration has required the limitation and transparency of financial funds' positions on agricultural commodity markets.
This advancement is the first step in countering the appetites of speculators.
The impact is dramatic for European breeders as well.
They are no longer able to feed their animals.
Hundreds of farms are in bankruptcy.
Five years ago, wheat was worth one hundred euros per ton; today, it is trading at nearly three hundred euros.
The rules of the game have thus changed completely.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to market signals; it would be well advised today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must confront the crisis, and I propose three concrete actions.
Firstly, the creation of cereal stocks in producing countries to make them available to breeders at subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, indexing the prices of meat paid to breeders on the evolution of feed prices.
Thirdly, for the year 2011, a mechanism to transfer a portion of the aids intended to support cereals to animal productions. Thank you.
Mr. President, are we prepared in Europe to face a pandemic?
The answer is yes, but there is a however.
capital. The H1N1 flu episode of two thousand nine showed us that each Member State reacted on its own, with little coherence or even solidarity.

As a shadow rapporteur on this file, I believe it was necessary to make these observations, but above all to go further, to be constructive and concrete for our citizens who, it must be said and this is indeed what seems most regrettable, have likely lost a bit of confidence in public health messages.

The report by Mrs Rivasi, which will be voted on tomorrow, takes into account these fundamental priorities, which include, among others, the systematic strengthening of cooperation between Member States and improved coordination with the...

European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of European structures for managing health risks, an assessment of the vaccination and communication strategies implemented in the Member States.
This is therefore a good report, and I congratulate the rapporteur. Obviously, it must not remain a dead letter.
It is the responsibility of our member states, which retain most of the competences in this area, and so it is a genuine responsibility towards our citizens.
Mr. President, I would like to express, in my turn, my profound emotion following the cowardly assassination on March 2nd of the Pakistani Minister responsible for Christian minorities, Mr. Bhattie.
This assassination, of a terrorist nature, follows numerous others of courageous Pakistanis, tolerant, lovers of human rights, defenders of human rights and women's rights, I must say.

Once again, we urgently call on the Pakistani government to shed full light on this cowardly assassination and to effectively, truly effectively, ensure the protection of those threatened by fanatical religious extremists.
I am thinking, of course, first and foremost, but not exclusively, of Mrs. Sherry Raymond.
I wished to also, once again, vigorously call upon all relevant institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations towards
prepare future cooperation agreements, including the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, with a clause upholding religious freedom and respect for human rights. Thank you.
Mr. President, for the record, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate and credit bubble, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit and the cumulative budget balance of central, local, and especially social security administrations were estimated at thirty-two percent of GDP in two thousand and ten.

If the Irish government, which is struggling to refinance itself through the markets, wishes to access loans from the European Financial Stability Mechanism and Fund, it will have to meet social and fiscal reform obligations, even though these areas fall under subsidiarity.
In our view, this is not contradictory.
As a physician, I would say that in the case of fever, it is futile to blindly prescribe antipyretics without attempting to treat the underlying cause.
In the event of the allocation of these funds, it is incumbent upon that state to undertake a financial restructuring in order to address its excessive deficit and rectify its previous errors.
This austerity plan is expected to increase GDP by ten percentage points over the next four years.

Just as an individual, without interfering in their private life and management, would condition a personal loan on a guarantee of solvency, so too can the European Union lend to Ireland based on consolidated solvency.
Without interfering in his private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, a salary increase or to borrow elsewhere.

By respecting subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the IMF, considers that this solvency requires a reduction in the legal minimum wage and an adjustment to pensions, without exempting itself from fiscal measures.
it is up to Ireland to decide whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not an open door to interference by the European Union in areas of subsidiarity, which could dangerously impose a European minimum wage level, but rather a protection of the stability of the eurozone through a process of mutual guarantee.

Of course, it is appropriate to assist Ireland, as well as other countries in distress, which also protects us, but not at any cost, especially not at the cost of seeing a state unable to repay its debts in the long term, thereby jeopardizing its own citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano last April, and many of us have said so just now, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and inefficiency of European airspace.
And each one of us in this chamber has been directly affected.
and five million of our fellow citizens found themselves stranded, without any real alternative transportation solutions.
One year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still pending.

A first crisis exercise, as you mentioned, Commissioner, related to volcanic ash is indeed scheduled for April 13th and 14th, under the coordination of Eurocontrol, the ICAO, and the IATA. However, it is crucial that EASA take on a genuine leadership role in coordinating safety measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse needs to be refined using more modern technological means.

These data, as seen last April, can however be contradictory and may lead each Member State to make decisions regarding the closure of their airspace that are less driven by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the EASA is crucial in providing a harmonized interpretation of this data, as well as ensuring the centralization and proper dissemination of information.
Beyond vaccinal information, EASA must implement a mechanism for collecting available data by closely involving Member States, airlines, and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all relevant stakeholders will prevent the chaos and inconsistencies we witnessed last year.
I therefore expect the Commission, together with EASA, to rapidly present concrete proposals that will fully contribute to the implementation of the European Single Sky.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
This is not a revolution; one cannot say that everything was wrong before and that everything is perfect now.
However, it does present a number of significant advancements at this provisional stage of our work.
The main issues, in my opinion, concern better regulation of distance selling, and in particular online, and this is chapter three because consumer rights in this area need to be strengthened.

E-commerce is highly beneficial, as it expands consumer choice, enables them to secure the lowest prices, and also provides small and medium-sized enterprises and artisans with new market opportunities.
To make progress in this area, it was necessary to do so in a truly European way, that is, on a few very specific points, to establish a complete harmonization of rights and obligations for all.
In very practical terms, an Italian customer buying on a Belgian or German website needed to know that, from now on, they will benefit from the same rights and the same protection.
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that its cooling-off period will be extended to fourteen days across the entire Union.
This means that he will immediately know the total amount he will have to pay, without fearing an unpleasant surprise afterward.
This means that, thanks to the double-click, he will correctly verify his order.
Obviously, all of this will disrupt certain habits.
In many states, there are nuances in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, even though sometimes they are not even found in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe means learning to adjust one's habits somewhat in the service of the common and general interest.
Let's be clear about this text: it will need further improvement, and we will have to work on it in the coming weeks with the Council and the Commission.
I appreciated the openings that have just been made in this regard.
But we have already accomplished substantial work thanks to our rapporteur, Andrea Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the true fruit of this labor is above all the fact that the amendments will be voted on tomorrow by all the political groups.
Consumer confidence in the European Union's internal market is very fragile.
It was necessary to have this political unanimity to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
At point number seven, after the first paragraph, a first dash should guarantee respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular,
freedom of speech and assembly, and the right to peaceful protest, and to listen to and address the legitimate demands of protesters, and to ensure their safety.

Madam President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, the open skies agreement between Europe and the United States is a step forward, but it is only a stage, a stage that places Europe before a dilemma.
The Transport Commission and the Commission themselves have emphasized this.
Either we accept an agreement that disadvantages European businesses, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits gained since two thousand eight.

Allow me, then, to draw a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, as the pilots among whom I count myself find themselves faced with a dilemma.
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency, seeking to harmonize licenses across the European territory, will do so to the detriment of eighty to ninety general aviation pilots.
directly affected, some holding only a single American license, and to the detriment of, and this is important, businesses and jobs associated with this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project, which has no security foundation.
There are thirty-one fewer accidents among American license holders.

The objectives of the basic regulatory text 216 allow for the recognition and equivalence of licenses, the benefits of which should not be delayed awaiting hypothetical agreements postponed until 2014.

Therefore, I suggest a very open-sky agreement and even invite you to accompany me when I occasionally come to Parliament, piloting the aircraft myself, to demonstrate that an American pilot's license is perfectly safe.
Madam President, at this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be led to repeat or to endorse some of the points that have already been made.
