But I also wanted to say that, like many of my colleagues, the problems we are facing, that the entire European Union is currently facing, cannot be resolved by any single Member State alone.
No member state should face the challenges ahead alone, which, once again, in my view, concern the entire European Union.
I am thus truly calling for the European Union's ability to organize itself and respond in a joint manner, in a spirit of solidarity.
I believe that the time has truly come now to lay the foundations for a genuine European policy on immigration and asylum.
Over a year ago, a European pact on asylum and migration was adopted.
The time has come now, I believe, to outline this in a very concrete manner.
So, we have indeed listened to Madame the Commissioner, we have heard a number of recommendations she made.
I wanted to revisit this and strongly emphasize certain proposals.
So yes, at all costs, Frontex's resources must be strengthened.
I believe that we need to strengthen Frontex's human, material, and financial resources, and enable it to provide more robust support to the Hermes and Poseidon operations.
Yes, additional financial resources are needed for member states that are confronted, I would say, primarily with the heightened migratory flows we are experiencing today.
And this will be the financial expression of our solidarity.
Yes, we must forge closer cooperative relations with the states on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, accompany them, of course, assist them, and identify appropriate tools.
The Commissioner, I believe, mentioned that she had gone to Tunisia to discuss mobility partnerships.
Yes, we must strengthen these instruments with a sense of responsibility, with a spirit of solidarity, but also with a clear and practical mindset. Thank you.

Commissioner, you are undoubtedly aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication have centered on the role of public services, services of general interest, within the single market and their legislative translation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that encourages you to go beyond your proposal twenty-five, and we ask you to go beyond a mere

communication that does not meet the expectations and needs of stakeholders, users, and all stakeholders in public services, and that also does not align with the objectives you have otherwise outlined.
The European Union must deliver a clear and unambiguous message regarding public services.
For this, we must create a positive legal framework, either a regulation or a directive.
The Treaty of Lisbon provides us with the legal foundations.
It is now up to you to translate them into legislative proposals.
I believe that Parliament is ready to follow you down this path.
Mr. President, firstly, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their gigantic work on this discharge, and I also welcome the presence of the Council for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and it is not solely an economic issue.

I am addressing this issue today in this chamber during the debate on the 2009 discharge because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the Committee on Budgetary Control as a mere means of making savings.
The issue of Parliament's expenditures also interests me.
In this regard, I suggest holding the group weeks in Strasbourg instead of Brussels, as this would enable us to make better use of our Parliament seat in Strasbourg.

Since we aim to save costs, I suggest implementing further measures. For instance, we could eliminate the daily allowance for Friday among our colleagues and also remove the per diems allocated to journalists.
Europe is sufficiently attractive that one should not feel obligated to offer a daily allowance to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond the scope of budgetary control, even though I welcome the important work of Villeux, our rapporteur, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are discussing economics, I also hope to see the moralization and improvement of the compensation system for sponsored visitor groups.

I do not find it very ethical, and it gives a very poor image of our institution, that the group leader is reimbursed in cash, in specie, on the day of the visit, without any work, and without any oversight of what the group has spent.
Sometimes, as I indicate to you, the allocated sum exceeds the amount of actual expenses.

It would be logical for groups to send a quote in advance to the visits service, to receive an account from Parliament for expenses, paid into a bank account, and for the balance to be paid on presentation of the invoices actually paid, with an obvious ceiling. Thank you.
Madam President, I am addressing the Commission, my colleagues, and I acknowledge the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in two thousand eleven.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; on the contrary, it is an area that has continually expanded in recent years and now comprises twenty-five states, three of which are non-members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it now covers, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this light that we must read the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
Mutual trust among the States party to the Schengen Area is indeed the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air pockets, the entire system becomes defective.
It should therefore be possible for other States to address this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly controlled checks at these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly encouraged to better secure their external borders.

Furthermore, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be taken at the European level, rather than intergovernmental.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to the full range of long-term measures envisioned with a view to a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex and provide greater solidarity to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation that the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years merely highlights a gap in the Schengen acquis.
In a matter of weeks, migrants from Mediterranean rim countries accounted for a significant percentage of France's annual immigration.
This achievement is not static but must, on the contrary, evolve.
I hope that these proposals will be adopted swiftly, ensuring better management of our Schengen area and thereby securing our common external borders. Thank you.
Mr. President, the European Union has finally imposed sanctions on Syria.
But unfortunately, she seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding any direct criticism of the Syrian regime's leadership.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the authorities as indulgence, allowing them to intensify the situation.
repression, a repression so cruel that one cannot imagine for a moment that at the same time, Syria could be elected to serve on the Human Rights Council of the United Nations organization.
of the United Nations, while even today, Syrian authorities are denying UN observers access to the city of Daraa, where terrible violence has been inflicted upon defenseless civilians.

Syria's presence on the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its own people, in blatant disregard for the very values that the Human Rights Council is supposed to uphold.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avert such a disaster?

Madame Mathieu, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who did exquisite craftsmanship on this report, and God knows it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen the control of their borders and have succeeded in doing so.
Whether it concerns police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or the control of air, sea, or land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
all technical criteria are met.
We can only acknowledge this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now able to implement this Schengen acquis in both technical and staffing terms.
Moreover, while no obstacles currently hinder this expansion of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be rigorously followed, especially with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece, and Turkey, as you know that the mutual trust between Schengen States is based on the full respect by these States of their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air pockets, the entire system becomes defective.
I earnestly hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council to welcome these two countries into the privileged circle formed by the Schengen States.
And we will all measure in this hemicycle the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Once again, congratulations to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
Mr. President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have broadly supported this objective, including almost all member states and our Parliament.
In this context, it is regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have sought to empty the new Eurovignette directive proposal of its content and to block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our rapporteur, and I would like to acknowledge Sad el Khadraoui here, thanks to his tenacity and that of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

Certainly, this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will allow for the first time the implementation of the polluter pays principle and the internalization of external transport costs such as noise or CO2 emissions.

In order for this eurovignette to be more than just a tax and to effectively contribute to the improvement of transport in Europe, member states are also encouraged to reinvest the collected funds in modernizing transport modes.
The Parliament has also managed to secure concrete inventions in the area of interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the policy objectives our institution has set for itself, I sincerely hope that we can adopt this compromise proposed to us at second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality with farmers and countries that have joined us from the East.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have taken a significant step forward with this report.
It was not easy at first, and we were rather in a confrontational situation, but we reached a consensus, and that is what matters most.
This consensus makes it possible to protect the overall project, and I believe this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We have achieved this goal, and it was not easy. I would therefore like to thank Rapporteur Murciudes and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the necessity of equality, justice, and equity among producers and among territories, and I believe this is important.
We have stated very clearly and confirmed the preservation and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms being indispensable for the quality and biodiversity of the regions.
I believe it was equally fundamental.
The fact that this concept of making agriculture agronomic, of turning the page on industrial, productivist agriculture, has been incorporated into the texts is significant.
Now it will be necessary to implement this. It is a condition to make agriculture possible for future generations.
This is not an ideological question.
Finally, today, our concern is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
It will need to be answered clearly.

Now, what we are expecting is that we will enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts and grand intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are heading, and that is what we are awaiting, of course, at this moment.
I would still like to end by uttering a cry of anger against Germany's attitude, which has resulted in a fivefold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was within the budget of the CAP.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest. There are eighty million European citizens who are not properly fed.
Mr. President, while the European Parliament can boast of some significant progress in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to show humility, for we are dancing on the edge of the abyss.
Let us be fully aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament remained unheard during the Greek crisis.
Whereas we are usually so quick to react to all sorts of events with resolutions around the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, simple message to the Greeks, to the governments of the Member States, and to European citizens.
The second observation pertains to the scope of this package.
By voting for these six directives and the regulation, we will undoubtedly enable the euro area to take a step forward.
more towards a discipline that we have so lacked, a step, I say, no more than that, which will demonstrate its usefulness in the future.

But it is enough to look at the fiery debates surrounding the overturned qualified majority to gauge the distance we still have to go, when it is rules and automatic sanctions that should be the focus.
The mechanism of reversed qualified majority voting continues to act as a bogeyman for some.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the benches of the left continue to reject the principles of sound budgetary management against all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are contradictory.

Yes, states must also manage their budgets prudently, like a good father managing his household, but not through public spending stimulus. It is a sweet poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks prove crucial, it is now a matter of reestablishing an economic union.
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a text that is highly significant for the advancement of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which could possibly account for twenty-five percent of all commerce in Europe within twenty years, which is quite considerable.
These purchases will notably be cross-border.
They will enable consumers to expand their choices and also pay much less.
This is a genuine progress.
For SMEs and all artisans, this is also a very important opportunity to expand their markets.

Among the key advancements, I would like to highlight two: the extension of the cancellation period to fourteen days, and the summary of all information and the total price to be paid before finalizing the order.

Finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to state that not only I, but all our colleagues, voted unanimously across the political groups, because on such a topic, what we needed was not controversy, but clearly consensus.
If we have obtained it.

Mathieu, two minutes. Welcome, Commissioner. Madam President, Madam and Mr. Commissioner, first of all, I would like to acknowledge the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very challenging file, which required a high level of technical expertise, extensive work, and in-depth knowledge of the matter.
The control of our shared territory and European borders is one of the most significant challenges we must address, and technological tools are more than ever at the service of this endeavor.
Indeed, in recent years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some refer to as a digital tsunami is certainly expected to materialize in the coming years.
The SIS, the VIS, and Eurodac are all essential tools today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring effective operational management of these databases is therefore a key issue for which it is our responsibility to provide an efficient solution.

This response is of course very delicate, and Carlos Coelho had to overcome numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political, and technical obstacles. Nevertheless, he managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all interested parties.
The establishment of this network agency indeed appears to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of the Member States.
No other existing institution or agency could currently assume responsibility for the proper management of these information systems.

It will enhance the management of existing information systems, provide better synergy between these databases, and additionally allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the very delicate questions that arose in this file was the location of the Agency's headquarters - where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have volunteered to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen information system in Strasbourg, for which it has been responsible for operational management and administration since 1995, and consequently has full technical control.
Following the conclusions of the European Council of December 2003, which prioritized the new Member States, Estonia also wished to host this future agency.

It seems to me that the compromise reached is excellent. A sort of division of tasks, Madam President, has taken place by transferring the Agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg.
The cost-effectiveness ratio is well-balanced, and this compromise solution does not in any way undermine the centralized management of IT systems.
Mr. President, the cross-cutting social clause and Article fourteen of the Treaty of Lisbon bindingly guarantee social rights, including the right of access to services of general interest.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

Therefore, we must afford our social rights the full recognition they deserve within EU law, acknowledging the specific nature of SSIGs (Social and Solidarity Economy Initiatives) in relation to competition rules. These services have a strong local presence and are based on social economy actors.

Mr. de Rosa's report provides an opportunity to affirm the simple yet powerful and significant principles of equality and universal access to these collectively organized services, which are drivers of well-being and social progress.
Madam Commissioner, you said it is time to move to the practical aspects.
Yes, it is time to move towards concrete action. In this debate, I propose that we actually create a European legislative instrument for social welfare services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution submitted by the Green Group.
Mr. President, debates concerning GMOs must imperatively be based on irrefutable arguments, both from a scientific and legal standpoint.
From a legal standpoint, member states wishing to restrict or ban GMOs on their territory needed arguments that were as varied as they were strong.
The rapporteur has expanded the range of maneuverability.
I, in favor.
As for the scientific basis, it too must be irrefutable.
The Council has repeatedly challenged the EFSA's scientific assessments, which are always positive about GMOs, unlike national scientific evaluations.

To restore trust, would it not be necessary, Commissioner, to simply apply the existing legislation aimed at providing significant scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council's recommendations of October 2008 remained a dead letter?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First and foremost, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Bouzitil for the outstanding work he has achieved.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal, and we can only congratulate him for it.
This report outlines an agency with enhanced capabilities, better aligned with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex is finally being given the resources to fulfill its mandates.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and avail of the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and highly efficient.
New tasks are also assigned to it, such as organizing voluntary returns and processing personal data, so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's scope of responsibilities enables us to address and consider migration issues through a comprehensive approach, rather than being limited to mere mechanical border management.
I approve of the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has fully asserted itself in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory council within the Agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal, which represents a step forward in achieving a healthy and responsible management of our external borders in a context of particularly intense and ongoing migratory pressures. Thank you.

Mr. President, I would like to thank Rapporteur Mr. Meyer and my colleagues for their remarks, sometimes critical, but this 2010 activity report is finally a remarkable opportunity to discuss the Petitions Committee, as it remains largely unknown.
Yet it is the Commission, with a direct, sometimes physical, link to the citizen, who can attend our debates themselves.
She has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament and a vast wealth of expertise due to her direct connection with citizens.
Indeed, any petitioner may go to the Parliament and defend their rights before the Committee on Petitions.
One can also commend the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be: attentive to its citizens' problems and united in finding solutions to protect them.
Unfortunately, the means of intervention and influence remain limited, particularly regarding the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes nearly completed.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will be conducting a mission on this very subject in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always expedite the provision of all necessary information to us.
I would like to thank the European Commission for its research and verification work, even if sometimes it could go further in the pursuit of truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
I finally call on citizens to continue to petition us, as directly elected representatives, to take action.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness, as it is our responsibility to underscore the extreme urgency of the situation.
Firstly, we observe that what was a priority yesterday remains so today, even more pressingly.

The lack of reliable statistical definitions and indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from observing, given the crisis, that the number of people living below the poverty line has increased, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to an estimated 84 million in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned with eradicating poverty, called on Member States to end the problem of STF by 2015.
Today, we have drawn a little closer to our goal ourselves.
Did the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, truly serve as an opportunity for member states to concretely address the significant precariousness that has become a permanent emergency?
I truly allow myself to doubt it, and I deeply regret it.

To conclude, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy on homelessness because, of course, there is misery and lack of housing, but there are also family problems, health issues, various addictions, and personal vulnerabilities.
A comprehensive, effective, and ambitious yet tailored approach is required, one that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their paths, and the disruptions in their lives.
This is a fundamental right, at the very least, from which a significant number of highly precarious individuals are excluded.
Madam President, as everyone has stated in recent years, the European Union has been struck by unprecedented disasters, and the cities mentioned here would take up all the debate time.
I will nonetheless cite the Azedef explosion, whose tenth anniversary we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A strengthened reaction at the European level, as proposed in Mrs. Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity among our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been attempting to make this pooling of our efforts operational, and it is now time to act together and no longer wait for a new catastrophe to strike our territories before learning from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our physical, human, and financial resources available to all, in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Madam Commissioner, earlier you said that we need to anticipate risks.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding from the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential instrument for disaster prevention and response coordination.
I urgently call on the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programmes that undeniably add value to Europe.
I would like to thank Mrs. Gardini for her excellent report.
I hope we will adopt it, as it will pave the way for European solidarity in the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to rise within the European Union.
Over forty-three million Europeans are at risk of food poverty.
The hour is grave.
Today, six member states wish to end the food aid program without any replacement solution: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Indeed, there is a decision by the Court of Justice, and we must respect it.
However, Mr. Commissioner, the Parliament called on you last July, at the initiative of our Green group, and you made relevant proposals to save the program.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but given that millions of people depend on this system, we cannot allow the food aid budget to be cut by four-fifths.
The emergency is real.

If nothing is done by the end of the year, over three hundred million euros will be missing from the food bank, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to step in to make up for this shortfall.
This is thus a real question of solidarity among peoples.
Let us not allow an irresponsible minority government to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because this is first and foremost a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We must fundamentally change our production methods to bring food production closer to the people, especially the poorest who are entitled to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and allow those in need to avail themselves of this vital aid.
I am addressing in particular the future Danish government, which will have the responsibility of ensuring the presidency of the European Union as of January.
Return to reason. Must there be food riots in Europe to realize the pressing need to change course?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, suddenly no one is available. The Parliament delivered a strong message last time: Human beings are more important than finance.
in terms of finances, it is high time to reaffirm this
In any case, we will remain very vigilant and will not fail to renew our constructive appeal.
Six member states hold the fate of eighteen million Europeans in need in their hands.
six member states that claim to be doing no more and no less than legalism.
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm bells sounded by the associations that aid the most vulnerable?

And we, European Parliament members, representatives of all citizens, do we want an Europe where national selfishness sets the policies, paying little regard to the citizens of states in budgetary distress?
There is no suggestion of renationalizing this aid.

No, let's maintain this program, let's give it a stronger legal basis, but let's not abandon those who, right now, in 2012, are counting on this support during a particularly severe crisis. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and in particular in Belgium, in Lige, ultimately resulting in hundreds of direct redundancies and jeopardizing several thousand indirect jobs.
As a resident of Lige, I share the astonishment and despair of the five hundred and eighty-one workers and their families who have been laid off.
But I also think of the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany, and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited are always the same: poor prospects for the evolution of the steel market in Europe, strong competition from imports from China and Korea.
Russia and Brazil, the shrinking of the automotive market, and finally, the competitiveness gap, for example, of the Lige site compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
Alongside this and despite a challenging year in 2010, the financial center of the steel group ArcelorMittal Belgium generated a profit of one billion three hundred eighty-four million euros.
He paid zero euros in taxes, which corresponds to a tax rate of zero.
This is particularly shocking.
The group's management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy implemented across multiple sites.
And the closure of sites is nothing more in the minds of these leaders than an economic adjustment variable where human concerns are of little importance.
This is no longer acceptable. So,
You spoke, Commissioner, of the rules.
Would it not be time for the Commission to develop a binding social responsibility code for multinational corporations?

It is already six years since our Parliament adopted a report concerning offshoring, the corporate code of conduct, subsidy repayment, and mandatory consultation between businesses, trade unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission plan to do about this and within what timeframe?
While it is necessary to support business competitiveness and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, it is also essential to adopt a legislative framework.
a strong Europe to cope with relocations and restructuring and ensure full consideration of another capital, human capital.
Finally, in the case of the Lige site, I hope that it will benefit from the intervention of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to support the laid-off workers. Thank you.

Madam President, dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs hitting workers across Europe should lead us to reflect on the role we, as policymakers, have to play in the face of multinational corporations acting with impunity.

without any social ethics, who carry out stock market layoffs and offshore to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies at the expense of social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of twenty September last on the future of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the Parliament clearly expressed its will to support above all employees affected by the negative effects of restructurings.
But we also asked the Commission to ensure coherence between GEF interventions and the European Union's industrial policy, particularly through the use of structural funds.

We also insisted that the future regulation of the EMFF include improvements so that the Fund does not have the same random, moral effects on multinational companies as it does today with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look at the issue of structural funds and the Globalization Adjustment Fund in isolation.
taking into account the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the cost-benefit ratio of a policy, I repeat, well...
Mr. President, the European Ombudsman brilliantly conducts investigations into complaints lodged against the institutions and bodies of the European Union.

This instrument is necessary to facilitate free movement, for our businesses and citizens alike, but it also serves as a powerful guarantee, especially in the face of the Union's detractors who all too often claim that the European Union is merely a bureaucratic machine devoid of control.
This is clearly a nonsensical situation. Europe is doing some serious self-reflection, thanks in large part to the European Ombudsman.
But let me relay a finding that I deeply regret, one in which the Commission is under heavy criticism.
Firstly, the correct figure is sixty-five, not twelve, representing the number of inquiries opened by the ombudsman concerning the European Commission.

There are also actors. Many businesses come to us to express their frustration with a European Commission that remains deaf to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. Similarly, on the issue of transparency in decision-making,
Few people find their way there.
Finally, from personal experience, I must confess that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain services of the European Commission present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission provides us with its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens that we see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer questions from an MEP or who take refuge in bureaucratic language almost as well as politicians, and this in front of citizens advocating their cause.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative issues addressed and resolved by the ombudsman are Europeans, relieved to be heard but disappointed by their outcomes.
citizen behavior, which is then negatively influenced by their confrontation with institutions, potentially fostering a sense of revolt, misunderstanding, and ultimately, perhaps, Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the mediator against institutions in general are heeded. Thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and the competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which today's subject is framed.
We, the EPP group, have lent our support to the report by our colleague Ms. McClarkin, to the drafting of which we have greatly contributed, and we obviously endorse it.

key recommendations of this report are for increased professional mobility, greater simplification and efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring patient safety and consumer protection.
But it is indeed in terms of the path to growth that the issue of increasing professional mobility arises.
Moreover, the forum for a single market held in Krakow at the beginning of October did not err in this regard.

who recalled that Member States needed to recognize the potential of the internal market to boost growth and job creation, and that they must act to remove all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
Similarly, the European Council of October 23rd last also set as one of the essential priorities for achieving, I quote, smart, sustainable growth,

Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our fellow citizens, it is a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people living in precarious situations by twenty million by the year 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authority.

We must, now more than ever, uphold the commitments made by the European Union in two thousand and ten during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion and at the launch of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion, in order to establish a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must secure and optimize European funds, particularly the aid program for the most deprived, which is currently being maintained, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at the horizontal level, and it is now time to act to enable the most disadvantaged to escape their precariousness.

As political leaders, at the European, national, and local levels, we must take the necessary measures to ensure them, without discrimination, access to housing, healthcare, justice, education, and a first job with a minimum income that can be indexed according to each member state's poverty threshold.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation, as well as in poverty reduction, will enable us to implement a sustainable, smart, and inclusive growth strategy.
The Europe we wish for and need today is a Europe of solidarity.

Moreover, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing be implemented, as this practice hinders the development of countries by reducing the financial resources they could derive from fishing economic activity.
Now, these resources are essential for developing countries to implement social, economic, and educational policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, promote the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the recipient states of the aid.
Adopting a holistic approach is necessary to stem the scourge of illegal fishing. Thank you.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Iturgaiz, on the quality of his work, for the lengthy negotiation process he had to lead, and for the patience he demonstrated.

Petitions concerning the environment are predominantly focused on waste, which is a significant concern among our fellow citizens.
This topic must address a societal issue.
We consume without restraint.
We are only now realizing that what we do not consume, we throw away.
This awareness must be absolutely strengthened among citizens, clearly.
But this report also serves as a reminder to Member States.
It is nonetheless concerning to see that the states appear to be unable to control the situation.
Only six member states have transposed the waste framework directive in time.

Finally, and this is the most concerning, organized crime appears to be doing as it pleases.
A market of seventy-five billion euros inevitably attracts covetousness.
States must send a strong signal.
There must be increased penalties for companies that abuse public contracts for personal gain.
This report serves as a warning signal to the states, but the European Commission must also play its part and ensure the proper implementation of the waste directives.
This file must be made visible, but also credible.
If no one cooperates, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and cross-verification processes that could drag on for years.
Let us heed the petitioners' message and halt this mess as soon as possible.

Madam Commissioner, the data protection standards of third countries still differ significantly from European standards.
It is, however, our duty to ensure that our prevailing European minimal standards of protection are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data are processed fairly and collected for specified, legitimate purposes.

European citizens must be able to enjoy a guaranteed right of access to and rectification of their personal data, as well as the right to initiate legal proceedings in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action is required to enable European and international standards to coexist and resolve a legal conflict that could be detrimental to European citizens.
European legislation alone is not sufficient.
It must be intelligently articulated and coexist with international standards, as we cannot shirk our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation resonates with other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European program for monitoring the financing of terrorism.
Such a system would provide us with a tool that has proven its effectiveness in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and thus the protection of personal data of European citizens.
European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully uphold their protection standards. Thank you.

In response to the crisis, the European Union has spent over a year strengthening its economic governance to prevent macroeconomic imbalances and excessive budget deficits that threaten the European economy. However, this has not prevented social exclusion or the rise in unemployment.
It is not just time, it is now urgent that the objectives of Europe's 2020 strategy become an absolute priority for the European Commission and for the Member States with a view to growth.

Each country will need to implement a national employment plan, which means that the focus should be on a wide range of topics such as, among others, training, retraining, microcredit, apprenticeships, paid internships, and so forth.

Now, as Commissioner Andorre pointed out earlier, we have twenty-three million unemployed people in Europe, but also twenty-three million SMEs and twenty-three billion European funds dedicated to employment and unused.
We could almost make this a 23-23 strategy.
And that's not counting the sixty billion euros in unallocated cohesion funds.
In Denmark and the Netherlands, social initiatives have been implemented and have proven effective, based on the principle of flexicurity.
Let us draw inspiration from it.

This also means that our overall social policy must be better adapted, with more advantageous social incentives than those linked to unemployment, and active support for all socially virtuous enterprises.
We had poverty reduction targets to meet by 2020, yet we already know these will not be achieved due to the lack of strong and appropriate measures taken by member states.

Our role as parliamentarians must therefore be fully exercised, and it is our responsibility to demand that the same energy expended on implementing robust economic governance measures also be directed towards ambitious, effective, and binding social governance measures.

I believe that taxation is an interesting tool for changing behaviors.

A month earlier, in this very place, we had a debate on the wave of layoffs in Europe due to the economic crisis, particularly at Arcelor, a multinational present in nine European Union member states, which is restructuring its production facilities in Europe in the face of declining steel demand.

With the shutdown of two blast furnaces in Belgium and Luxembourg, and the idling of a blast furnace in France, it is estimated for the year two thousand twelve that nearly six direct jobs are at risk.

Beyond unacceptable practices such as stop-and-go, which should be better regulated, it is the broader question of European steelmaking and adaptation to change that requires extremely urgent responses.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to refute the unfounded allegations of the circulation in France of five hundred to one million fake biometric passports that are said to be in circulation in our country.
France takes the risks of fraud concerning identity documents very seriously.
It does not take infractions in this matter lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is an offense punishable by one year in prison and a fine of fifteen euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, enabling prefectures to allocate additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, in each prefecture, a fraud liaison officer is appointed.
Furthermore, the security measures for issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, the civil status data provided can be verified between administrative services, insofar as possible, in a dematerialized manner in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same rigor applies to supporting documents for proof of residence.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path towards enhanced security for proof of residence documents through the inclusion of a barcode.

The classic treatment of a title request includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents produced in previous title requests, and the potential authentication of supporting documents.

The secure issuance of titles is further guaranteed by the double appearance of the applicant, first at the time of filing the application and then at the time of collecting the title, along with the taking of two fingerprints.
And without mentioning the enhanced checks for the renewal of lost and stolen documents for comparative purposes with the data held by the prefectures, I conclude.

Furthermore, France informs international cooperation bodies, notably Interpol, about passports issued, lost, or stolen to prevent their fraudulent use.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, firstly, it is evident that our fellow citizens are increasingly seeking to find and consume locally produced and seasonal food, particularly for reasons of health and quality.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and swiftly to this growing demand.

We must support the development of local infrastructures for producers, such as maintaining local slaughterhouses, which, while ensuring rigorous health controls, enable the growth of local short-supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers market their products and raise awareness among consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable farmers to retain a larger portion of the added value generated on their farms.

It is necessary to promote and facilitate direct sales on the farm and to support collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points, thereby offering local consumers a wider range of products.

The European Commission should facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct sales systems through delivery to consumers, such as AMAPs (Association for the Maintenance of Peasant Agriculture) in France, which enable nearly three farmers to supply sixty families.
Finally, member states should be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning farm size, production volume, or the traditional nature of the product, to define local agriculture. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am pleased that this amending budget concerning the financing of ITER, which was voted on with a large majority in the Budgets Committee on March 29th,
By funding this additional cost, we avoid abandoning a strategic project in fundamental research in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.
Let us recall that none of the seven partners in the Euratom community has called into question its overall contribution to the project.
Japan, despite the Fukushima disaster, has decided to scrupulously honor its budgetary commitments to ITER.
Without this agreement, hundreds of researchers would have had to suspend their work, and the ITER project would have faced detrimental delays.
Today, a thousand people work for ITER at Cadarache.
From 2015 until 2017, the construction phase of the buildings and the assembly of the machine could mobilize up to four people on this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. Rapporteur, thank you for the work we have accomplished together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a shared political vision for the major challenges related to the environment, towards 2020 and beyond.
This is why it is so important to launch a seventh environmental action program, by synergizing existing financial frameworks and mobilizing new funding resources.
This program must ensure consistency and alignment between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture,
fishing, research and innovation, health, transportation, regional development, territorial planning, and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is affecting the European Union, we must not give in to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate realm.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, especially regarding the efficient use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and eco-innovation, a source of growth, competitiveness, and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote ecodesign, recycling, but also the environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumer choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental pedagogy, essential for European citizens.
The environmental action program is a political policy instrument, but it is also a communication tool.

It must provide the necessary readability and predictability for national and local administrations, citizens, but also entrepreneurs and investors, regarding the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, in the face of the profound changes our world is undergoing today, the EU must reform its generalized preference system.
Like any compromise, this one does not deviate from the rule.
While it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial perspective, it is far from perfect, as we must bear in mind that this regulation is intended for developing countries.
In developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission states its intention to refocus its action in support of the poorest countries.
This does not seem at all tenable at first glance.
To achieve this, the Commission has nonetheless developed a strictly accounting-based vision, relying solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
We clearly see the limitation of this approach.
What about the many middle-income developing countries with undiversified economies that are vulnerable to climate shocks?
The compromise reached with the Council does not address this issue, which is why I call on colleagues to vote in favor of the three amendments that will be tabled on this text.
Commissioner, the issue of the availability of public consultations in the various languages of the European Union is unfortunately not a new one.

This is, in my view, a crucial question, for which I have already not only submitted several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally questioned Mr. Barroso in writing.

Indeed, the Commission must adhere to the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as recalled by the Court of First Instance of the European Communities in its judgment of November 20, 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the response from the European Commission, which stated that public consultations do not claim to provide a fully representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission acknowledges that certain positions and views may be overrepresented at the expense of others.
This is not an answer.
I am inquiring about the criteria that would enable us to measure the overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not overrepresented due to their availability in English alone, they fail in their purpose of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result provides a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we wish to maintain written consultations as a tool underpinning the legislative proposals of the European Commission, we must ensure a democratic, transparent, and fair process for all citizens.
Therefore, if the European Commission opts for written consultations, it must take responsibility and allocate the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle.

The analysis should also take into account the overly short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately mostly accessible to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed regulation aims to grant the European Commission increased powers to oversee national budgets and economic policies.
The rules are about to become stricter, and failing states will have budgetary cuts and structural reforms imposed on them by Brussels technocrats in order to restore their financial balances.
This heightened surveillance is called a guardianship.
States will be punished, fined, one could say spanked, with financial sanctions that will be strengthened and made more automatic.
Even if certain amendments aim to prevent solely budgetary austerity through growth measures, your proposals are merely there to sweeten the pill.
Growth, as you know as well as I do, cannot be decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, following the technique of the Chinese thief, the European bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian state has finally been established, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Mr. President, without undermining the importance of the economic choices we must make, allow me to emphasize a remark of a more political nature within the context of this debate.
In recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-speak of certain European leaders, or those who consider themselves as such.
While everyone continues to advocate for economic, budgetary, and fiscal policies that are finally worthy of the name, and this requirement even appears to be a condition,
a sine qua non for the survival of the eurozone, it is now Mr. Cross Maline who, once comfortably settled in his home, is decrying the balanced recommendations emanating from
the Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst-case scenario, to turn public opinion against these 'Brussels bureaucrats', as they call them.
This irresponsible attitude might be laughable if we were not in such a tragic situation.
I'll be straightforward with you, our discussions on stability, the necessary consolidation of public finances, or the efforts to be made in terms of growth are indeed doomed to...
failure if the past mistakes regarding debt and public deficit do not cease and if the governments of the Member States continue on their disastrous path.
We are playing with fire right now.
European discipline must apply to all, without exception, including the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
This requires a minimum of courage, and our public opinions are ready for it, far more than some of their leaders are willing to believe.
And a final word to Ms. Goulard, unless I have to show her the blue card, I would say, to conclude with Ms. Goulard, in redemption, there is ransom.

Mr. President, I would like to firstly commend the determination of the European Commission, and in particular yours, Mr. Commissioner, for tirelessly placing the revival and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

As you recalled, Commissioner, it has already been more than two years that both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to pinpoint the challenges and sectors that require more internal market integrationmore internal market for greater growth, enhanced competitiveness, and more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also eventually came to emphasize the great importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
Rather than continually seeking to invent new growth instruments, we are better off working with the toolkit we already have.

We therefore take the opportunity of the resolution that will be put to the vote of our Assembly tomorrow to send a strong political message to the Member States on the need for greater speed and effectiveness in transposing directives already adopted.
adopted to encourage greater mobilization and commitment in the newly opened fields. I will cite only one example: that of strengthening worker mobility, with greater ease and fluidity of movement.
We will welcome with great interest, Commissioner, the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will know how to demonstrate both political willpower and the ability to apply pressure on member states.
We witnessed the mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the breast implant scandal, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the failings in European health safety.
This breast implant scandal, these fourteen years of fraud from 1996 to 2010, unpunished,
There are five hundred prostheses worn worldwide, eight implant removals, and forty-eight confirmed cases of cancer.
Finally, three complaints have been filed. These figures are alarming and shocking.

How, despite the warnings of the American Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and lawsuits regarding prosthesis failures filed in Great Britain and France in particular, were national and European agencies able to overlook such a scam?
This tragedy promptly led us to consider enhancing the European system for controlling medical devices, as you just explained to us.
We must, Commissioner, today build a new system capable of preventing scandal, but it is a new system that we must construct.
This new legislation is announced for the fall, as you have indicated.
As a co-author of this resolution, I am, of course, satisfied with it.
But, Commissioner, you seem to want to take into account a large part of our concerns as dictated by this resolution.
So why make an unacceptable exception for many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why not advocate for the establishment of a market authorization for the highest-risk Class III medical devices?
Commissioner Dali, could you please explain your position to me?
Mr. President, currently, we are experiencing a situation with a production increase of over two and a half percent. At the same time, manufacturers are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England, and across all European countries, prices are falling.
Which means very clearly that prices are linked to the volume of production, and we need to organize production volumes while also managing prices.
At the same time, today, producers are victims of an increase of more than forty-four percent in the price of plant proteins and thirty percent in the price of cereals.
The Parliament has already voted on the need to ensure that the surplus value is shared among producers and that farmers are not victimized by businesses and large retailers.

I therefore call on the Commission today, but also on the Council, to reconsider the challenge to the control of production, but at the same time, I am saying very clearly that Member States must put their own house in order, because there are countries that have respected the quota rules and others that have not.
And this, too, is what led to these quotas being challenged.
So there is a dual responsibility, that of the Commission and the Member States.
Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, a single European railway area, this is a fine policy for European integration.
Here is a fine policy where European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often criticized for its failures, Europe, through this directive, finally charts the course for a major policy on sustainable transport and paves the way for a significant railway investment policy to create jobs.

I welcome the key measures adopted in the organization of the rail network, including the establishment of national regulators in each Member State and the creation of a five-year multi-annual investment contract, thereby setting out the funding commitments of the latter.

railway infrastructures, but also I welcome the establishment of financial flow transparency between managers and operators within integrated companies. The reminder about non-discriminatory access to certain

services. Finally, I welcome the confirmation sought by European parliamentarians of certain guarantees, particularly on the social front, such as the absence of a reference to minimum service, as well as full unbundling between the network manager and the operator.

But allow me to raise one requirement that we should stop considering, particularly from the European Commission, namely the liberalization of the rail sector as the only strategic horizon for the development of a single rail area, and instead decide on an integrated European investment strategy that supports employment in Europe.
Similarly, I would like, to conclude, to ask you a question, Commissioner Callas.
It is three days after the European Council of June twenty-eighth and twenty-ninth, following the validation of a 120 billion growth pact to boost the European economy.
specifically through investment in infrastructure. Can you tell us, Commissioner, what amount the European rail sector is likely to benefit from under this growth pact?
Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but tonight I would like to address an issue, albeit peripheral, that is extremely important in this context.
These are the remarks made by Commissioner Gutt before the International Trade Committee on Wednesday, June twentieth.

I quote: "If you decide on a negative vote before the European Court rules, let me tell you that the Commission will nevertheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice."
We are committed to it.
A negative vote will not halt the procedure before the Court of Justice.

justice. Not only do these statements, in my view, misrepresent the treaties, but more importantly, and this is what I wish to highlight, they demonstrate an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, democracy in general, and the citizens we represent.
Here, at a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President. At this point, much has been said.
Sir, Commissioner, for my part, I would like to thank you very warmly.
Thanks to your obstinacy and procedural rigor, you allow us to demonstrate the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for inspiring hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and for two million eight to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is played out here, that we, the European elected officials, are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Thank you once again to the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who are still following us today.
I greet them. It's a breath of fresh air in our institutions, too often perceived as technocratic.
Sir Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is also another principle.
This is the fundamental principle, the one of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take responsibility, and I would like to thank you tomorrow as well for taking responsibility for your failure, the failure of your work method.
I speak on behalf of Maurice Ponga, shadow rapporteur for the Development Committee on Mr Gallagher's report.
It seemed important to me to reiterate that the European Union, when it wishes to sanction a country that engages in unsustainable fishing, must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of policy coherence for development, it is crucial, in my view, that the measures adopted on fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Development Committee by stipulating that measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives, and to ensure that the level of development and vulnerability of countries are duly taken into account. Thank you.
This third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these sea plunderers, solely responsible for the poor health of fish stocks, as environmental organizations and the European Commission claim when they lump all categories of fishing together.

It is, of course, necessary to conserve fish stocks, but we must also enable our fishing communities to earn a living from their activities and preserve the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Now, the main measures of the European executive once again aim at reducing the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than fifty since nineteen eighty.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the introduction of individual transferable quotas, which are seen as guarantees of industrialization and sector concentration, or even a total ban on discards, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project likely suits the industrial fleet, but in its current state, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur, our colleague Karins, on this challenging report, given the sensitive nature of bilateral negotiations in the energy sector between European countries and third states.
The agreement reached in trilogue will enable the rapid implementation of the Commission's draft decision, and in the interests of pragmatism, this can only be welcomed.
Europe's energy transition is progressing, albeit not quickly enough.
As a major energy importer, the European Union finds itself structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to foster a more European perspective on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to more widely disseminate information on energy agreements within the European Commission, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will thus enhance transparency in the energy market and enable the anticipation of energy supply issues.
I am pleased that this decision does not create an obligation with regard to agreements between commercial companies.

In times of crisis and given the stakes involved in competition and competitiveness, we had a duty to protect the interests of our businesses and the rules governing the protection of private contracts.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this file.

It was necessary because we were starting from a very long way back with the Commission's basic proposal, with no specific mention of the ultra-peripheral regions directly affected by competition from Latin American countries, and no automatic trigger.

from the stabilization mechanism, no possibility for our Assembly to request the opening of a safeguard investigation, no consideration of social and environmental standards as potentially constituting unfair competitive advantages.
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote endorses the progress made on these points in the International Trade Committee.
Despite everything, it is not sufficient because we know that the trigger thresholds for these two regulations are so high that they render these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Moreover, the Commission must allocate an additional financial envelope to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Keep in mind that many jobs are at stake in these European regions that already have record-high unemployment rates.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking Charles Goerens for his excellent report.

We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total official development assistance, and yet, as we approach the deadline for the MDGs in two thousand and fifteen, even though some targets seem to be within reach,
Affected as we are, we must ask ourselves how to improve our aid, to make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments with short- and medium-term timelines.

The economic crisis, climate change, the rising power of emerging countries, and land grabbing compel us to establish new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Indeed, a European consensus exists, but we need to rethink European and international institutional systems regarding environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from organizations that effectively make decisions, such as the WTO, for instance.
Finally and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not merely a matter of charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
One need only look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries such as China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better consider the geostrategic evolution of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were, until recently, still developing nations.
Henceforth, as indispensable economic powers, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at the European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join my colleagues from other groups, as well as those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, in calling for two thousand and fifteen to be designated the European Year of Development, and above all, of responsible development.
Mr. President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission, in my view, raises many questions, the primary one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission intends that, starting in two thousand fourteen, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid will be based on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of per capita wealth.
Now, as Mrs Ashton reminded us, these issues are not merely a matter of accounting, but warrant a genuine political debate on defining our priorities in international cooperation.
Moreover, this differentiated approach, in my view, is not in keeping with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, let us applaud the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall fell.
Despite this, despite all the progress we have witnessed since the start of our debate, it is undeniable that the single act today is synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
I would therefore like to hear from you, Mr Barnier, Commissioner, to tell us how we are going to build together a fairer Europe, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

There are a number of avenues to explore, and I would like to hear your thoughts on these central issues of the economic and social crisis as we, unfortunately, know it: fiscal harmonization, public services,
protector of the minimum wage in Europe, implementation of enhanced cooperations, job-creating, facilitating cross-border cooperations and developing a fair trade policy.
These, I believe, are the challenges that lie before us twenty years on.
I am counting on you, Commissioner, for us to carry forward this fine policy of European construction together.

Mr. President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have taken a keen interest in the report by my colleague Regina Bastos concerning the twenty main concerns of citizens and businesses.
and we debated this report, which is linked, incidentally, to our discussion on the twentieth anniversary of the internal market.
It has already been twenty years since the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital was supposed to be fully realized within our living space, our area of exchange, our internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that at the forefront of the issues expressed by our European fellow citizens is the existence of professional qualifications, and that we truly need to be especially proactive and highly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens are expecting in order to truly establish, in the very near future, recognition procedures for their diplomas, skills, and professional qualifications that are much faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
This is a real challenge.

As the shadow rapporteur for the EPP Group on this topicthe modernization of these proceduresI am actively working with the other members of the IMCO committee to address this major challenge of mobility.
greater mobility, for a stronger Europe, is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
Mr. President, this year the Committee on Petitions has acquired the right to be automatically associated for the hearing of European Citizens' Initiatives.
This is the strong signal for me from the year two thousand and eleven for this Commission.
Citizens already had a commission to turn to in cases of breach of their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions can increasingly be seen as the citizens' privileged interlocutor in the European Parliament.
This issue of consideration is also reflected in the outcomes of the Petitions Committee's positions.
Too often, we are approached by citizens facing legal entanglements on which we would like to take a stance. But while the issues are European, we find ourselves...
that solutions should be European, we remain powerless because subsidiarity still does not align with European solutions due to a lack of national will.
I will use the challenging example of transnational divorces. The issues are both national and European when custody or visitation rights cross national borders, in this case, those of Germany.
Despite the glaring difficulties for many parents in seeing their children born of binational unions, we remain in Parliament still powerless to act.

My proposal that all European citizens have the right to a national ombudsman, especially from Germany, which sends a large number of petitions based on the model of the Defender of Rights in France, has had no effect.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, it remains a solution that reconciles the European problem with the national solution.
In many cases, European law appears powerless to meet the expectations of citizens.
The European Year of Citizenship 2013 must address the grievances of citizens, listen forcefully, but we need means to act in order to be.
